This program allows you to search protein databases for sequences that match any MySQL-recognized regular expression. This makes it possible to quickly search for more complex motifs. For example, if you want to match a sequence that contains AAP followed by an unknown number of unknown residues followed by VAP, you can directly search for a pattern like that by using the regular expression AAP.+VAP . Be aware that these searches are greedy, ie. if you include quantifiers (like ?, +, or *) the search will always try to include as much into its result match as possible. For example a search for PA.+[VP] on a sequence APALLLKVARPLLM will match
A PALLLKVARP LLM
instead of
A APALLLKV ARPLLM
.
Please note that since the regular expression you enter here goes directly into the MySQL query, so you must use the proper MySQL regular expression syntax (such as using "." rather than "X" to mean "any residue")! See the examples below for further clarification.

Examples:
MySQL uses greedy quantifiers!
LSTP matches only LSTP.
L[ST]P matches LSP and LTP.
LS.P matches LSXP.
LS.+P matches LSXP, LSXXP, LSXXXP, etc. (1 or more X's).
LS.*P matches LSP, LSXP, LSXXP, LSXXXXXXXP, etc. (0 or more X's).
LS.{2,4}P matches LSXXP, LSXXXP, and LSXXXXP only (2 to 4 X's).
^ML.N matches MLXN only at the N-terminus.
ML.N$ matches MLXN only at the C-terminus.
